text.content: Click a Lesson or Activity to learn more about What Is a Temper Tantrum?
A temper tantrum is when a young child has an extreme behavioral reaction to overwhelming negative emotions.

Tantrums usually start small with whining or looking frustrated, and then escalate into:
  • Screaming and sobbing
  • Kicking and hitting
  • Throwing self on the floor
  • Holding breath

Most children will have a temper tantrum at some point in time, and some will have more frequent and more intense tantrums than others. Tantrums often begin between 12 and 18 months, and are commonly seen in 2- and 3-year-olds. Tantrums can continue into the grade school years for some children.

Factors that impact the frequency and intensity of tantrums include a child's:
  • Temperament
  • Emotional development
  • Environment
  • Parental reaction

Key Messages:
  • Tantrums are a normal part of a child’s development.
  • The way that children react to emotional situations is influenced by their developing brain.
  • The frequency and intensity of tantrums decreases as children grow older.
  • Children learn from their parents and caregivers how to effectively manage their emotions.

graphic.notes: istock File #: 4172646 or similar, angry crying child
Child in a temper tantrum, istock 4176290 or similar

audio.transcript: A temper tantrum is when a young child has an extreme behavioral reaction to overwhelming negative emotions. Tantrums occur because a child's emotions can be more powerful than their ability to manage them.

Tantrums usually start small with whining or looking frustrated, and then escalate into screaming and sobbing, kicking and hitting, throwing oneself on the floor, or holding the breath. Temper tantrums feel out of control to the child, and can be frightening to the child as well as to the child’s parent.

Most children will have a temper tantrum at some point in time, and some will have more frequent and more intense tantrums than others. Tantrums often begin between 12 and 18 months, and are commonly seen in 2- and 3-year-olds. Tantrums can continue into the grade school years for some children.

Factors that impact the frequency and intensity of tantrums include a child's temperament, emotional development, the environment, and the parental reaction to the tantrum. All of these factors also influence how quickly a tantrum can be resolved.

The Key Messages for this section are that: Tantrums are a normal part of a child's development. The way that children react to emotional situations is influenced by their developing brain. The frequency and intensity of tantrums decreases as children grow older, and children learn from their parents and caregivers how to effectively manage their emotions.
